string_table.string: Closed captions. Press the spacebar to toggle captions on and off.
Skip navigation. Press enter to return to the slide.

slidelink.displaytext: Rules of the Road for Safe Drivers
At 60 mph, the average reaction time is 60 to 135 feet.

search.slidetext: --- start course start course start course start course start course start course safe driver awareness fleet services

%project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides% download the course companion to follow along download the course companion to follow along 3 2 policies & procedures regarding driving vehicles for university business 1 safe driver awareness this module is approximately 20 minutes long basic safe-driving guidelines information to make you an even better driver

2018 2019 211 $450,000 accidents 2013 alone, work-related crashes cost employers $25 billion %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides% 2003-17 > 27,000 workers in the us died in a work-related motor vehicle crash
distracted driving driver attitude defensive driving alcohol & driving seat belts we will cover: promote safe driving practices %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides% fleet services

%project.slidenumber% of %project.totalslides% uc davis injury & illness prevention program uc davis policies and procedures university safe driving guidelines new information %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
1 rules of the road for safe drivers %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
what makes a safe driver? 10 rules of the road for safe drivers always drive safely and responsibly! %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
distractions and fatigue cause thousands of crashes a year pay attention! 1 %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
safe driving requires your full attention driving distractions manual visual cognitive %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%

distractions distractions distractions well done! well done! well done! business bulletin g-46 business bulletin g-46 business bulletin g-46 fatigue fatigue fatigue %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides% let’s talk about fatigue let’s talk about fatigue let’s talk about fatigue difficulty focusing difficulty focusing difficulty focusing %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides% frequent blinking or heavy eyelids frequent blinking or heavy eyelids frequent blinking or heavy eyelids yawning repeatedly or rubbing eyes yawning repeatedly or rubbing eyes yawning repeatedly or rubbing eyes daydreaming; wandering/disconnected daydreaming; wandering/disconnected daydreaming; wandering/disconnected trouble remembering the last few miles driven; missing exits or traffic signs trouble remembering the last few miles driven; missing exits or traffic signs trouble remembering the last few miles driven; missing exits or traffic signs trouble keeping head up trouble keeping head up trouble keeping head up drifting from your lane, following too closely or hitting a shoulder rumble strip drifting from your lane, following too closely or hitting a shoulder rumble strip drifting from your lane, following too closely or hitting a shoulder rumble strip feeling restless and irritable feeling restless and irritable feeling restless and irritable don’t “push on” – instead stop & rest don’t “push on” – instead stop & rest don’t “push on” – instead stop & rest signs that you should stop and rest signs that you should stop and rest signs that you should stop and rest eating or drinking talking to a passenger/phone adjusting dashboard widgets personal grooming no texting or phone calls %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides% the university of california business bulletin g-46 the employee is expected to avoid using a cellular phone or any other type of electronic communications equipment under any circumstances where such use might create or appear to create a hazard, including use while operating a motor vehicle. “ %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides% 1 distractions distractions distractions distractions distractions click the boxes to learn important facts about safe driving click the boxes to learn important facts about safe driving click the boxes to learn important facts about safe driving click the boxes to learn important facts about safe driving business bulletin g-46 business bulletin g-46 business bulletin g-46 business bulletin g-46 business bulletin g-46 fatigue fatigue fatigue fatigue fatigue %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%

well done! well done! well done! %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides% protect your eyes maintaining alertness while driving keep cool by opening the window or using the air conditioner avoid heavy foods be aware of down time during the day take turns driving take periodic breaks drink caffeine in moderation avoid drugs %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides% feeling drowsy? stop and rest %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides% preventing drowsiness before a trip get adequate sleep prepare route carefully schedule trips for the hours you are normally awake drive with a passenger avoid medications that cause drowsiness consult your physician if you have sleep problems incorporate exercise into your daily routine %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides% %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides% are you at risk? how to prevent fatigue how to prevent fatigue how to prevent fatigue %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%

incorrect that is incorrect. please try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect you should never use your phone when driving. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue test your knowledge select the actions that are considered distracted driving. taking your eyes off the road taking your eyes off the road taking your eyes off the road taking your eyes off the road taking your eyes off the road taking your eyes off the road taking your hands off the wheel taking your hands off the wheel taking your hands off the wheel taking your hands off the wheel taking your hands off the wheel taking your hands off the wheel taking your mind off the task of driving taking your mind off the task of driving taking your mind off the task of driving taking your mind off the task of driving taking your mind off the task of driving taking your mind off the task of driving leaving your phone in your bag and not checking messages leaving your phone in your bag and not checking messages leaving your phone in your bag and not checking messages leaving your phone in your bag and not checking messages leaving your phone in your bag and not checking messages leaving your phone in your bag and not checking messages click the submit button
yield anyway! 2 %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%

pedestrians always have the right of way pedestrians always have the right of way pedestrians always have the right of way you can be ticketed for not respecting a crosswalk you can be ticketed for not respecting a crosswalk you can be ticketed for not respecting a crosswalk wait patiently for pedestrians wait patiently for pedestrians wait patiently for pedestrians %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%

check your driving for these behaviors: check your driving for these behaviors: check your driving for these behaviors: %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides% driving aggressively tailgating making rude gestures failing to yield to merging traffic flashing high beams changing lanes without signaling honking the horn excessively passing on the shoulder
beware and be patient beware and be patient beware and be patient %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%

incorrect that is incorrect. please try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect false. pedestrians always have the right of way. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue true true true true true true false false false false false false test your knowledge click the submit button if no crosswalk is available, pedestrians don’t have the right of way.
backing up is dangerous 3 90% crashes human error drive cautiously be prepared to react %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%

vehicles are designed to drive forward backing up is dangerous backing accidents 30% watch for potential hazards %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides% legally, the driver is usually at fault in backing accidents follow these safety guidelines…
make sure to turn your head and scan either sides behind you %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
inspect your path before backing up watch for potential hazards always check the path behind you %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
guide to reversing signals try to avoid backing whenever possible try to choose easy-exit parking spaces %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides% recruit a helper to guide you
become acquainted with a vehicle before driving it %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
become acquainted with a vehicle before driving it %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
always back up slowly %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%

incorrect that is incorrect. please try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect false. side mirrors should be set to eliminate blind spots, not to see directly behind the vehicle. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue true true true true true true false false false false false false test your knowledge click the submit button side mirrors should be set to eliminate blind spots, not to see directly behind the vehicle.
4 rushing is futile the highest ticketed violation is speeding speeding and collisions are closely linked 15 mph > speed limit= reckless driving %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
speeding is very expensive $500 for first time offenders 15-20 year-olds most likely to speed %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%

incorrect that is incorrect. please try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect the highest ticketed violation for motor vehicles is speeding. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue test your knowledge the highest ticketed violation for motor vehicles is… driving too slow driving too slow driving too slow driving too slow driving too slow driving too slow speeding speeding speeding speeding speeding speeding driving and talking on the phone driving and talking on the phone driving and talking on the phone driving and talking on the phone driving and talking on the phone driving and talking on the phone running a red light running a red light running a red light running a red light running a red light running a red light click the submit button
5 don’t drive impaired 40% of fatal crashes cause by alcohol-impaired driving 1 alcohol-related fatality/30 minutes %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%

alcohol + driving = collision 39% of all work- related collisions 1.5 million people arrested/year for dui %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides% other legal & illegal drugs are also being used amphetamines narcotics prescription drugs over-the counter drugs substances that can make driving unsafe { dui may result in suspension of drivers license and/or discipline from the university
california legal blood alcohol level over age 21 = 0.08% under 21 = 0.01% %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
commercial drivers legal blood alcohol level commercial drivers = 0.04% you can be arrested even if slightly impaired %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
the cost of drinking and driving %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
and more… %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
dui is costly %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
6 2,699,000 were injured 39,404 people were killed seatbelts save lives %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides% buckle up!
most effective way of reducing rusk of death or serious injury wearing a seatbelt reduces the risk of injury or death in a collision by 45-60% %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
seatbelts save nearly 12,000 lives/year seatbelts prevent 325,000 serious injuries/year %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
seatbelts are not to be shared contact fleet services for repair %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
%project.slidenumber% | %project.totalslides% airbags add to the safety provided by seatbelt %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
airbags activate in front and side collisions %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
anti-lock brake systems are another safety feature %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%

incorrect that is incorrect. please try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect you must always wear a seat belt even if you are a good driver. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue test your knowledge select the correct answers. if you are a good driver, you… won’t get into a crash won’t get into a crash won’t get into a crash won’t get into a crash won’t get into a crash won’t get into a crash still need to wear a seat belt still need to wear a seat belt still need to wear a seat belt still need to wear a seat belt still need to wear a seat belt still need to wear a seat belt your passenger doesn’t need a seat belt your passenger doesn’t need a seat belt your passenger doesn’t need a seat belt your passenger doesn’t need a seat belt your passenger doesn’t need a seat belt your passenger doesn’t need a seat belt have a better chance to survive an accident if wearing a seat belt have a better chance to survive an accident if wearing a seat belt have a better chance to survive an accident if wearing a seat belt have a better chance to survive an accident if wearing a seat belt have a better chance to survive an accident if wearing a seat belt have a better chance to survive an accident if wearing a seat belt click the submit button
chill out and avoid road rage! 7 %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
chill out and avoid road rage! stay calm put your pride aside avoid eye contact ignore rude gestures %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
when in town… lock the car doors keep windows & sunroof partly open leave enough space when in traffic think happy thoughts %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
weather factors %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
when driving in the fog… %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
when driving in the snow… %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
when driving in the rain… if hydroplaning… %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%

incorrect that is incorrect. please try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect when driving in the fog, you should reduce your speed. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue reduce your speed reduce your speed reduce your speed reduce your speed reduce your speed reduce your speed turn off your fog lights turn off your fog lights turn off your fog lights turn off your fog lights turn off your fog lights turn off your fog lights follow other vehicles closely follow other vehicles closely follow other vehicles closely follow other vehicles closely follow other vehicles closely follow other vehicles closely flash your headlights to warn others flash your headlights to warn others flash your headlights to warn others flash your headlights to warn others flash your headlights to warn others flash your headlights to warn others test your knowledge click the submit button select the correct answer. when driving in the fog, you should… select the correct answer. when driving in the fog, you should…
8 create space! %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
8 always observe the 2-second rule one thousand one one thousand two %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
8 reaction time speed limit 60 = 135 feet 176 feet to respond %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
8 traffic lights leave space %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%

incorrect that is incorrect. please try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect at 60 mph, the average reaction time is 60 to 135 feet. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue true true true true true true false false false false false false test your knowledge click the submit button at 60 mph, the average reaction time is 60 to 135 feet.
9 drive to communicate %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
signal all turns turn on the headlights %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%

incorrect that is incorrect. please try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect you must always use your turn signal and turn on your headlights whenever visibility is reduced. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue test your knowledge select the statements that communicate good driving practices don’t drive in other driver’s blind spots don’t drive in other driver’s blind spots don’t drive in other driver’s blind spots don’t drive in other driver’s blind spots don’t drive in other driver’s blind spots don’t drive in other driver’s blind spots don’t bother using your turn signal don’t bother using your turn signal don’t bother using your turn signal don’t bother using your turn signal don’t bother using your turn signal don’t bother using your turn signal turn on your headlights whenever visibility is reduced turn on your headlights whenever visibility is reduced turn on your headlights whenever visibility is reduced turn on your headlights whenever visibility is reduced turn on your headlights whenever visibility is reduced turn on your headlights whenever visibility is reduced change lanes as many times as possible change lanes as many times as possible change lanes as many times as possible change lanes as many times as possible change lanes as many times as possible change lanes as many times as possible click the submit button
10 take care of your vehicle %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
vehicle maintenance checklist keep gas tank at least half full conduct safety inspection before trips %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%

%project.slidenumber% of %project.totalslides% vehicle maintenance checklist conduct safety inspection before trips look under the car for loose parts pop the hood & check fluid levels and hose conditions check tire pressure and condition make sure gauges operate in the normal ranges adjust driver’s seat and clear items in the cab make sure interiors light and seatbelt work properly wiper blades should be replaced regularly fleet services 530-752-0789 %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
california vehicle code visit california highway patrol %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides% dmv driving safely guide

incorrect that is incorrect. please try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect you should call fleet services at 530-752-0789 and not drive the car. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue test your knowledge select the correct answers. what should you do if a car from the ucd fleet services is damaged? call the uc davis police call the uc davis police call the uc davis police call the uc davis police call the uc davis police call the uc davis police call your insurance company call your insurance company call your insurance company call your insurance company call your insurance company call your insurance company don’t drive don’t drive don’t drive don’t drive don’t drive don’t drive call fleet services at 530-752-0789 call fleet services at 530-752-0789 call fleet services at 530-752-0789 call fleet services at 530-752-0789 call fleet services at 530-752-0789 call fleet services at 530-752-0789 click the submit button

facilities.ucdavis.edu/fleetservices facilities.ucdavis.edu/fleetservices contact us fleetservices@ucdavis.edu fleetservices@ucdavis.edu 530-752-1199 530-752-1199 fleet services %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%
exit course exit course exit course restart course restart course restart course congratulations, you’ve completed this course. fleet services %project.slidenumber%|%project.totalslides%

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="According to the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health on March, 2020--In 2013 alone, work-related crashes cost employers $25 billion.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="From 2003-2017, more than 27,000 workers in the U.S. died in a work-related motor vehicle crash. UC Davis had 211 reported accidents in 2018-2019, with over$450,000 in claims for Fleet Vehicles and $500,000 in payments to 3rdparty for vehicle accidents. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="This figure does not include the potential Workers’ Compensation claims that may have resulted from such accidents." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="That is why we are happy to introduce this Safe Driver Awareness Program for the Campus. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="This course, sponsored by Fleet Services, is open to staff, faculty, and students who drive on University business. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="We’ll discuss distracted driving, driver attitude, defensive driving, alcohol and driving and seat belts. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="The overall goal of this program is to promote safe driving practices.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="We believe that proper training ensures that employees recognize hazards and can take the proper precautions. One of our objectives is to raise awareness of your role and responsibilities as a driver of a University vehicle and decrease your chances of being involved in an accident. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text=" This class is required by the UC Davis Injury and Illness Prevention Program and we know what you’re thinking, 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Why I’ve been driving for decades and I know what I’m doing, you’re probably right, but in this course we’ll discuss UC Davis Policies and Procedures regarding University vehicles, basic safe driving guidelines and perhaps even give you some new information to make you an even better driver.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Let’s get started. Please click next to continue.
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="In this section of the training, we will take a look at what makes a safe driver.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="We will review the top 10 rules of the road for Safe Drivers.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Remember, most drivers overestimate their driving ability. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="It is important to remember that all drivers make mistakes. Simply assuming that you are a great driver will not protect you from crashing.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Also remember that driving a motor vehicle is a privilege that can be taken from you. It is important to drive safely and responsibly. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="The following rules, if followed, will help to ensure safe, collision-free driving for operators of University vehicles.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Rule number 1. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Pay Attention!
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Distractions and fatigue at the wheel are responsible for thousands and thousands of crashes a year.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Distracted driving is estimated to be a factor in 20-25% of all the traffic crashes – that is 4000 of more crashes per day. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Distracted drivers fail to recognize potential hazards in the road and react more slowly to traffic conditions.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Safe driving requires your FULL attention!Distracted driving can be broadly defined as “any non-driving activity a person engages in that has the potential to distract them from the primary task of driving and increase the risk of crashing.” 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Specifically, there are three types of driving distraction:Visual-taking your eyes off the road
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Manual-taking your hands off the wheel
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="and Cognitive-taking your mind off the task of driving
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Rule number2. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Yield anyway!
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="A substantial number of the 6.8 million crashes that occur each year are estimated to be caused by aggressive driving, which often results in failure to yield. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Here are a few things to remember.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Pedestrian always have the right of way, regardless of whether or not there is a crosswalk.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="And if there is a crosswalk, you can be ticketed for entering it before a pedestrian has exited it completely.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Be sure to wait patiently for pedestrians." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Check your driving for these behaviors:
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="You may be driving too aggressively, tailgating, making rude gestures, passing on the shoulder, failing to yield to merging traffic, flashing your high beams at the car in front of you, changing lanes without signaling, or honking your horn excessively.
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="All these behaviors result in driving that is too aggressive and if you are guilty of any, take stock, beware and be patient." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Rule #3: 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Backing up Is Dangerous! 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Over 90% of motor vehicle crashes are caused by human error.Drive with caution in mind. Be alert for possible collision situations and be prepared to react.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="It is an obvious fact, but it’s worth noting for our purposes: vehicles are designed to drive forward. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Backing a vehicle is more dangerous than driving forward because of the lack of visibility, it is literally impossible to see the ground directly behind your vehicle from the driver’s seat unless you have a backup camera. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="This is a major reason why backing accidents account for approximately 30% of all accidents, even though mostly backing is done under 10 mph. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="The UC Davis campus has bollards, bikes, and pedestrians, among other potential backing hazards. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="The legal reality is that the driver is usually at fault when an accident or collision involves backing. But the good news is that backing accidents are avoidable by following a few simple safety guidelines.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="If your vehicle is equipped with a backing camera, use that as your primary view while backing, but don’t forget to glance around on either side frequently to check for hazards just outside your field of view. If you don’t have a backing camera, do not rely only on your mirrors, make sure to turn your head and scan either side behind you.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="It is always a good idea to do a walk-around of your vehicle to see what may be in your path before attempting to back
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text=" Objects close to the ground, such as bollards, curbs, and children can be impossible to see from the driver’s seat. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Once you’ve determined it is safe to back, immediately begin backing while checking the path behind you—don’t wait, because the situation can rapidly change.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="If possible, recruit a helper to stand behind the vehicle and help safely guide the driver while backing. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Agree to hand signals ahead of time, and make sure both driver and helper know exactly where the vehicle is going. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Should you lose sight of the signaler while backing, stop the vehicle immediately until you can reestablish the connection.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Since backing a vehicle is an inherently dangerous operation, try to avoid backing whenever possible. You might be surprised by how much you can avoid backing up by planning in advance to avoid backing situations. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="If you can’t avoid backing, try to choose easy-exit parking spaces that have adequate spacing.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Blind Spots exist in every vehicle but each is different based on the size and shape of the vehicle. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Because of this, drivers should always take the time to acquaint themselves with a vehicle before getting behind the wheel. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="The size of your blind spots can vary dramatically depending on the type and size of vehicle you’re driving. In particular, rear visibility can be quite compromised in larger vehicles, which makes them susceptible to backing into shorter and low hanging obstacles.
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Make sure mirrors are properly positioned to provide maximum visibility. Remember, side mirrors should be set to eliminate blind spots—not to see directly behind the vehicle. To accomplish this, side mirrors should be angled away from your vehicle, so that no part of your vehicle is visible in the side mirror, and the field of view just slightly overlaps with the rear-view mirror. If you can see your own vehicle in your side mirror, chances are you still have a blind spot behind and away from your vehicle, which will require you to glance over your shoulder to safely change lanes.
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Always back up slowly. Maintain constant vigilance of your surroundings and stay alert for anything that might suddenly get in your way. Slower backing enables quicker stops.
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Rule number4.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Rushing is futile.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="The highest ticketed violation for motor vehicles is speeding.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Speeding is said to contribute to 30% of all motor vehicle collisions. One of the highest percent of all possible factors.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="In surveys 60% of people admit exceeding the speed limit by 10 miles per hour. And 30% admit exceeding the speed limit by 20%.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="And remember that going 15 miles per hour over the speed limit is considered reckless driving.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Speeding is not only dangerous, it is also very expensive.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="If you are caught driving 100 miles per hour or more can cost up to $500 for the first time offense.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="People 15-20 years of age are most likely to speed.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Rule number 5.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Don’t drive impaired.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Alcohol-impaired driving accounts for 40% of fatal crashes, representing an average of one alcohol-related fatality every 30 minutes
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Alcohol is a contributing factor in 39% of all work- related collisions.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Nearly 1.5 million people are arrested each year for driving under the influence commonly called DUI. And two thirds of all drivers arrested for DUI are first time offenders. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Besides alcohol, other legal and illegal drugs are being used more often. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Laws prohibit possession or use of many drugs while driving. They prohibit being under the influence of any “controlled substance,” amphetamines, narcotics, or any other substance, which can make the driver unsafe. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="This could include a variety of prescription and over-the-counter drugs (cold medicines), which may make the driver drowsy or otherwise affect safe driving ability. It is important to remember that even if the drug is legal to use, it may not be legal to use while driving and could result in suspension of your drivers license and/or discipline from the University.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="In California, the maximum legal blood alcohol content for a person over the age of 21 operating a motor vehicle is 0.08%.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="The maximum blood alcohol content for a person under 21 is 0.01%, the lowest detectable amount.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="The maximum legal blood alcohol content for commercial drivers in California is 0.04%, as you can see, lower than regular class C drivers.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Contrary to popular belief, time is the only sure-fire way to sober up.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Remember, you can be arrested for a DUI if you are impaired to the slightest degree – whether it is due to alcohol, drugs, or any other impairment.
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Here’s what drinking and driving could cost you.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Vehicle towing, $50 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Storing the vehicle $50 per day
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Booking, fingerprinting and phot fee, $156
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Driver’s license reinstatement fee, $125
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Time payment charge, $35
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Totaling $416
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Whew! Wait, there is more.
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Car insurance increase, $1000 for 3 years
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="First offense DUI fine, $1588
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Assessment for the court system, $816,
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Community service fee, $150
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="DUI victim’s fund, $100
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Alcohol Abuse education fund, $50
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="DUI classes, $550
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="DUI Victim’s Impact sessions, $20
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="and let’s not forget public transportation for one year, $500-800
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Rule number 6.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Buckle up.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="In the 6,159,000 reported motor vehicle crashes in 2019, 39,404 people were killed and another 2,699,000 were injured. Seatbelts played an important role in these accidents.
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Here are a few facts about seatbelts:
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Seatbelts are the most effective means of reducing the risk of death or serious injury in a crash. Simply wearing a seatbelt reduces the risk of injury or death in a collision by 45-60%. Drivers age 16-20 have the lowest seatbelt use rate.
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Seatbelts reportedly save nearly 12,000 lives and prevent 325,000 serious injuries in America each year. 
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Seatbelts are not to be shared.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="If a seatbelt is broken, contact Fleet Services immediately and do not carry a passenger until it is repaired.
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Airbags add to the safety provided by your seatbelt.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Airbags are designed to activate in front-end (and in some vehicles, side impact) collisions.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="They are not a replacement for seatbelts – if you are not wearing a seatbelt and the airbag deploys, you can still be seriously injured. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="The seatbelt slows the impact of your body hitting the airbag. airbags and seatbelts are designed to work together.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Anti-lock brake systems are another safety feature that work with seatbelts to minimize collisions and injury.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="ABS systems use sensors to monitor the speed of the wheels. When the wheels lock up, the sensor releases the brake on the wheel to stop it from skidding.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="You should feel a pulse in the break pedal when this happens, but do not release pressure on the pedal.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Most new vehicles in the fleet have anti-lock brake systems.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Now it's your turn.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Test your knowledge." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Rule number 7.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text=" Chill Out and avoid road rage! Road rage is defined as extreme aggressive driving which we discussed earlier.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="There are a few things you can do to avoid being a victim of road rage:
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="First, stay calm. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="If another driver is being aggressive or unsafe, get out of their way as soon as possible. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Put your pride aside. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Do not challenge an aggressive driver by speeding or attempting to hold-your-own. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Avoid eye contact. Eye contact can sometimes enrage and aggressive driver.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="and finally, Ignore rude gestures and do not return them.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="In town, lock the car doors and keep the windows and sunroof only partly open. When stopped in traffic, leave enough space to pull out from behind the car you are following. And finally, think happy thoughts.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Now that we’ve prepared you for the human factors that can cause accidents, there is also the weather factor to consider. Many accidents occur in bad weather, which can be frustrating and confusing for some drivers. It is important to remain calm in these situations and to adjust your driving to the conditions. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Here are some simple guidelines for you to follow:" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="When driving in the fog, reduce your speed and do not stop on a highway unless it is an emergency. If you have fog lights, turn them on. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="When driving with snow chains on the highway, remember that the speed limit is always 30mph." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="When driving in the rain, your vehicle can hydroplane at a speed of just 30mph. If your car starts hydroplaning, ease your foot off the gas until your car slows and you can feel the road again." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Now it's your turn.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Test your knowledge." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Rule number 8
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text=" Create space! Whether driving in good weather or foul, it’s always a good idea to create some space between you and the next vehicle.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Always observe The Two-Second Rule. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Watch as the vehicle ahead passes some object then count “one-thousand-one, one-thousand-two.” If you pass that same object before getting to “two”, you’re too close!
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="At 60 mph, the average reaction time is 60 to 135 feet. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Two seconds of following distance at 60 mph means there’s over 176 feet of pavement to react and respond.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="It is also important to leave space when you’re stopped for a light. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Leave room in front so you can pull away if the car ahead stalls or doesn’t move, or if you need to move because of danger approaching from behind.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Rule #9: 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Drive to communicate. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="You communicate a lot when behind the wheel, and here are some positive messages you can give.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Position yourself in a lane (left or right) so other drivers can see you. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Don’t drive in other driver’s blind spots. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Make sure to signal ALL turns. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Make certain your brake lights and turn signals are functioning properly. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Turn on your headlights whenever visibility is reduced.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="And finally, Rule number 10
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Take care of your vehicle. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Here’s a very simple but effective Vehicle Maintenance Checklist.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text=" Keep the gas tank at least half full. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="A safety inspection must be conducted before every trip. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="The purpose of this inspection is to ensure vehicles are in proper working order and that it is safe to operate. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="This inspection should take less than 15 minutes
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="to complete. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Look under the vehicle and check for loose parts or leaking fluids, then check all exterior light condition and operation, pop the hood and check all the fluid levels and hose condition. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Check tire pressure and condition. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Start the vehicle and check the gauges operate and are in the normal ranges. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Adjust the driver’s seat to fit you and clear the cab of loose items or garbage. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Make sure interior lights operate and check all seatbelt functions, remember to never carry more passengers than you have seatbelts for. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Wiper blades should be replaced regularly.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="If anything doesn’t look right before your trip, call Fleet Services 530-752-0789 and don’t drive the vehicle.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Before we end the course, we would like to remind you that there are new sections being added to the California Vehicle Code every year. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="It is the driver’s responsibility to be aware of these changes. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="A good way to keep current on these changes is to visit the California Highway Patrol website at Http://www.chp.ca.gove/.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="The California Department of Motor Vehicles offers a complete guide driving safely. We provide the link onscreen and under the resources menu.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Please click next to continue.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Thank you for joining us today! 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Please contact us if you have questions.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="For resources, visit our website or click the Resources link at the top of the player.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="And above all, DRIVE SAFELY!!!!
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="When you are ready, click next to exit this course.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>
